issues.description: Constructor / attribute mismatch for Animal: the UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int) (problem_statement.md shows this in the UML). However, both the provided template Main (which constructs Seal/Pig/Goat with a single String argument) and the solution's Animal.java implement a single-argument constructor Animal(String) and no age attribute. This inconsistency will confuse students about the required constructor signature and whether an age attribute must be present.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the constructor/attribute mismatch by choosing one of the following consistent options: (A) Update the problem statement UML and descriptions to remove the age attribute and require only a single-argument constructor Animal(String), or (B) Update the template and solution to include the age attribute and a two-argument constructor Animal(String, int), and update all subclass constructors (Seal, Pig, Goat) and any example code (Main) to pass both name and age. Apply the same choice consistently across problem statement, template, and solution.

issues.description: Inner contradiction in the problem statement about Animal attributes: the textual description says "All three animals have something in common: they have a name" (implying only name is required), while the UML explicitly includes an age attribute for Animal (name: String and age: int). This conflicting description vs UML can mislead students when they implement the Animal class and its constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the problem statement so text and UML match. Either explicitly state that animals have both name and age and that constructors must initialize both, or remove the age attribute from the UML and state that only name is required. Ensure the textual description, UML diagram, and sample/template code are consistent.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int), but both the template usage (Main.java example) and the provided solution implement Animal with only a name and a single-argument constructor Animal(String). This mismatch between the problem's UML/spec and the code (template & solution) creates confusion about the expected Animal API and constructor signature — students may follow the UML and implement/expect a two-argument constructor (or vice versa), leading to compilation errors or wasted time reconciling the difference.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the API consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement/UML to remove the age attribute and the two-argument constructor (change UML to show only name and Animal(String)) so it matches the template and solution; or (B) update the template and solution to include the age field and a two-argument constructor Animal(String, int), and adapt all subclass constructors (Seal, Pig, Goat) and example usages in Main to pass an age. Choose one approach and apply it to problem_statement.md, the template code, and the solution so students see a single, consistent expected API.
